questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of double vision and unilateral right eye pain that began this morning. His vision improves when he covers either eye. He has hypertension, mild cognitive impairment, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, donepezil, metformin, and insulin with meals. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 132/75 mm Hg. His right eye is abducted and depressed with slight intorsion. He can only minimally adduct the right eye. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Extraocular movements of the left eye are normal. An MRI of the head shows no abnormalities. His fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 325 mg/dL. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ptosis occurs in patients with CN III palsy because the levator palpebrae superioris muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Whereas patients with CN III palsy due to compression usually show dilated pupils, those with diabetic mononeuropathy normally do not have pupillary involvement because the microangiopathy typically involves the vasa nervorum within the oculomotor nerve, while the pial blood vessels (which supply the superficial parasympathetic fibers) are usually spared.

CN III palsy due to diabetic or hypertensive microangiopathy usually improves with blood pressure and glycemic control. Patients should be monitored closely (every 2 days) during the first week. If the diplopia, ptosis, and/or external ophthalmoplegia worsen during this period or persist after 3 months, an MRI should be performed.
Image Description:

Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

B) INCORRECT:

A dilated and fixed pupil in a patient with an oculomotor nerve palsy is typically seen with compression (e.g., from an aneurysm, tentorial herniation) or complete transection of the oculomotor nerve (e.g., base of the skull fractures) because the parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction are located superficially on the oculomotor nerve. However, there is no clinical or radiological evidence of elevated intracranial pressure and/or hemiparesis to suggest tentorial herniation, or a history of trauma to suggest a skull base fracture; aneurysms only account for approx. 5% of cases of isolated CN III palsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Miosis and anhidrosis are seen in patients with preganglionic and central Horner's syndrome. Although patients with severe long-standing diabetes mellitus may present with Horner's syndrome as a result of diabetic autonomic neuropathy, Horner's syndrome is not typically associated with CN III palsy.
Image Description:

Orbital region of a female patient

The left eyelid is drooping (ptosis), the left pupil is smaller (miosis) than the right, and the left bulbus appears sunken into the orbit (enophthalmos).

Ptosis, miosis and anhydrosis (not shown) represent the classical triad of Horner syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Bitemporal hemianopsia occurs with lesions that compress the optic chiasm such as a pituitary adenoma, craniopharyngioma, meningioma, or a hypothalamic glioma. A tumor at the optic chiasm is unlikely to cause an isolated CN III palsy. Also, the MRI is normal in this patient and does not reveal a sellar tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

A positive swinging flashlight test indicates a relative afferent pupillary defect. An afferent pupillary defect is caused by retinal and/or optic nerve lesions (e.g., central retinal vessel occlusion, extensive retinal detachment, optic neuritis), and not by lesions of the oculomotor nerve, which transmits the efferent impulses of the pupillary reflex. A patient with an afferent pupillary defect would also have decreased visual acuity in the affected eye, whereas this patient has 20/20 vision in both eyes.
questions.hint: The most likely cause of isolated oculomotor nerve palsy in a patient with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is diabetic mononeuropathy, which occurs as a result of microangiopathic ischemia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of double vision that began this morning. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and insulin. Physical examination shows the right eye is abducted and depressed with slight intorsion. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Extraocular movements of the left eye are normal. Serum studies show a hemoglobin A1c of 11.5%. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Inability to abduct the right eye
Absent consensual light reaction on the right eye
Loss of the right nasolabial fold
Upper eyelid droop on the right eye
Absent direct light reaction on the right eye

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has an isolated oculomotor nerve palsy due to his poorly controlled diabetes, as the right eye is abducted with slight intorsion. Abduction of the eye is governed by the abducens nerve (CN VI), which is unlikely to be affected by diabetic microangiopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

An absent consensual light reaction on the right eye would suggest a defect of the parasympathetic fibers of CN III, which are responsible for pupillary constriction. Because microangiopathy typically involves the vasa nervorum within the oculomotor nerve, the pial blood vessels (which supply the superficial parasympathetic fibers) are usually spared. Therefore, one would not expect to see a pupillary defect.

C) INCORRECT:

The nasolabial fold, along with most facial movements, are controlled by branches of the facial nerve (CN VII), which is unlikely to be involved by diabetic microangiopathy.

D) CORRECT:

Ptosis occurs in patients with oculomotor nerve palsy because levator palpebrae superioris is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Whereas patients with oculomotor nerve palsy due to compression usually show dilated pupils, those with diabetic mononeuropathy normally do not have pupillary involvement because the microangiopathy typically involves the vasa nervorum within the oculomotor nerve, while the pial blood vessels (which supply the superficial parasympathetic fibers) are usually spared.
Image Description:

Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

E) INCORRECT:

Anosmia occurs through dysfunction of the olfactory nerve (CN I). Neither this patients symptoms nor the likely etiology of his condition (diabetic microangiopathy) suggests involvement of the olfactory nerve.

F) INCORRECT:

Microangiopathy typically involves the vasa nervorum within the oculomotor nerve, while the pial blood vessels (which supply the superficial parasympathetic fibers) are usually spared. Because both CN II (responsible for detecting light on the retina) and the parasympathetic fibers of CN III (responsible for pupillary constriction) are intact, there is no pupillary defect when light is shone on the right eye. Of note, if this patient's oculomotor nerve function had been caused by compression (such as uncal herniation), the parasympathetic fibers running superficially along CN III are actually first to be affected.
questions.hint: The most likely cause of an isolated oculomotor nerve palsy in a patient with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is diabetic mononeuropathy, which occurs as a result of microangiopathic ischemia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two weeks ago, he was treated in the emergency department for head trauma after being hit by a bicycle while crossing the street. Neurological examination shows decreased taste on the right anterior tongue. This patient's condition is most likely caused by damage to a cranial nerve that is also responsible for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The vagus nerve (CN X) provides the uvula with motor function. It also carries somatosensory and taste fibers that innervate the epiglottis and the most posterior part of the tongue, but not the anterior two-thirds. CN X is the most important parasympathetic nerve in the human body and innervates the intestines up to the splenic flexure of the colon. In addition, CN X is responsible for innervating the chemo- and baroreceptors of the aortic arch, elevating the posterior tongue and soft palate during swallowing, and the cough reflex.

B) INCORRECT:

Sensory innervation of the face is provided by branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) – namely the ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves. CN V provides somatosensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue; it does not carry special sensory fibers for taste perception. CN V is also responsible for the motor function of the muscles used in mastication (the masseter, temporalis, medial and lateral pterygoid muscles).

C) CORRECT:

Closing the eyelids is accomplished through the contraction of the orbicularis oculi muscle, which is, like all facial muscles, innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII). The chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve innervates the taste buds of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. The facial nerve is also responsible for innervation of the lacrimal gland, submandibular and sublingual glands, and the stapedius muscle.

D) INCORRECT:

Tongue protrusion is made possible by the extrinsic muscles of the tongue, which are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII). CN XII is an exclusively motor nerve that also provides the intrinsic tongue muscles with motor function. The only extrinsic tongue muscle that is not innervated by CN XII is the palatoglossus muscle, which elevates the posterior tongue when swallowing.

E) INCORRECT:

Parotid gland salivation is controlled by parasympathetic fibers of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). While CN IX carries somatosensory and special sensory taste fibers, it does so for the posterior third of the tongue rather than the anterior two-thirds. CN IX is also responsible for transmitting somatosensory information for the middle ear and eustachian tube, innervating the chemo- and baroreceptors of the carotid body and sinus, and innervating the pharyngeal muscles and muscles of the upper GI tract.
questions.hint: Taste on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is mediated by cranial nerve VII.

questions.text: One week after being involved in a bicycling accident, a 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent double vision. She reports worsening of symptoms when she tries to type on her computer or while buttoning her shirts. Physical examination shows a slight right-sided head tilt. Her left eye is deviated upwards, which becomes even more prominent when she attempts left eye adduction. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to impaired innervation to which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The superior oblique muscle is innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV) and is responsible for abduction, internal rotation (incyclotorsion), and depression of the eye during adduction. Impairment of this muscle manifests with vertical and torsional diplopia that worsens when the patient looks down and toward the nose (e.g., while typing on a computer); expected examination findings include external rotation (excyclotorsion), and upward deviation (hypertropia) of the affected eye. Downward gaze is impaired when the affected eye is adducted. The contralateral head tilt in this patient may be conscious or unconscious and serves as a compensatory mechanism.
Image Description:

Trochlear nerve palsy (here of the left eye) causes paralysis of the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle. This leads to hypertropia (upwards deviation) that increases in adduction, excyclotorsion (outward rotation) of the affected eye and slight limitation of abduction. The findings may be discrete.

Patients typically present with vertical or oblique diplopia. Hypertropia and diplopia usually increases with ipsilateral head-tilt and decreases with contralateral head-tilt. Patients may adopt the latter as a compensatory posture (upper right of image).

B) INCORRECT:

The superior rectus muscle is responsible for elevation, incyclotorsion, and adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause vertical diplopia, limitation of upgaze in the ipsilateral eye, and downward eye deviation (hypotropia).

C) INCORRECT:

The medial rectus muscle is responsible for adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause horizontal diplopia, limitation of the ipsilateral eye to the medial gaze, and deviation of the eye outwards (exotropia).

D) INCORRECT:

The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for abduction of the eye and is innervated by the abducens nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause medial deviation of the eye (esotropia) at primary gaze, an ipsilateral abduction deficit, and horizontal diplopia that worsens when looking at distant objects.
Image Description:

Abducens nerve palsy (here of the left eye) impairs the function of the lateral rectus muscle. This causes esotropia (medial deviation) of the affected eye and limits its abduction. Patients present with horizontal diplopia that worsens when turning the gaze to the affected side or looking at distant objects.

E) INCORRECT:

The inferior oblique muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve and is responsible for excyclotorsion, elevation, and abduction of the eye. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause the eye to deviate downwards (hypotropia) and rotate inwards (incyclotorsion).
Image Description:

Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

F) INCORRECT:

The inferior rectus muscle is responsible for depression, excyclotorsion, and adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause vertical diplopia, limitation of downgaze in the ipsilateral eye, and upward eye deviation (hypertropia).
questions.hint: This patient's right-sided head tilt, diplopia, upward deviation of the eye that worsens during adduction, and history of blunt trauma to the head suggest palsy of the left trochlear nerve (CN IV).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a persistent tingling sensation in the right side of his face. The sensation began after he underwent an extraction of an impacted molar 2 weeks ago. Examination shows decreased sensation of the skin over the right side of the mandible, chin, and the anterior portion of the tongue. Taste sensation is preserved. The affected nerve exits the skull through which of the following openings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The foramen magnum serves as the passage for the medulla oblongata, accessory nerve (XI), vertebral arteries, spinal arteries, and spinal veins. The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve does not exit the skull through the foramen magnum.

B) INCORRECT:

The hypoglossal canal serves as the passage for the hypoglossal nerve, not the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve. Lesions of this nerve would result in atrophy and fasciculations of the tongue on the side of the lesion and deviation of the tongue to the ipsilateral side.

C) CORRECT:

The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve exits the skull through the foramen ovale. A lesion of this nerve, as is most likely present in this patient, results in ipsilateral decreased sensation of the skin over the mandible, chin, parts of the auricle and the temple, the buccal mucosa, and the anterior ⅔ of the tongue. The mandibular branch also provides motor innervation to the muscles of mastication. The other structures that pass through the foramen ovale are the accessory meningeal artery, the lesser petrosal nerve, and the emissary veins connecting the cavernous sinus with the pterygoid plexus.
Image Description:

Superior view of internal surface

D) INCORRECT:

The foramen rotundum serves as the passage for the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, not the mandibular branch. A lesion of this nerve would result in anesthesia to the mid-face, not to the lower part of the face, as seen in the patient here.

E) INCORRECT:

The jugular foramen serves as the passage for the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), vagus nerve (X), accessory nerve (XI), and the internal jugular vein. The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve does not exit the skull through the jugular foramen.

F) INCORRECT:

The stylomastoid foramen serves as the passage for the facial nerve, not the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve. Lesions of the facial nerve at this level would cause peripheral facial nerve palsy, which presents with paralysis of the ipsilateral eyelid, forehead, and lower facial muscles.

G) INCORRECT:

The superior orbital fissure serves as the passage for the oculomotor nerve (III), the trochlear nerve (IV), branches of the ophthalmic nerve (V1), the abducens nerve (VI), and the superior ophthalmic vein. The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve does not exit the skull through the superior orbital fissure.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms suggest a lesion of the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3).

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of episodic coughing whenever he cleans his left ear. There is no history of hearing loss, tinnitus, or vertigo. Stimulating his left ear canal with a cotton swab triggers a bout of coughing. The physician informs him that these symptoms are caused by hypersensitivity of a cranial nerve. A peripheral lesion of this nerve is most likely to manifest with which of the following findings on physical examination?

choices.text: Decreased secretion from ipsilateral sublingual gland

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inability to raise the ipsilateral eyebrow is a sign of a peripheral facial nerve palsy (CN VII), which could also lead to eyebrow and mouth drooping, and further symptoms depending on the height of the lesion (e.g., sensory disturbances, dry mouth, ocular features). A lesion of CN X does not affect the muscles of facial expression.
Image Description:

Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Ipsilateral deviation of the tongue would be a sign of a lesion to the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII). Damage to this cranial nerve could also lead to atrophy and fasciculations of the tongue. A lesion of CN X would not affect the motor function of the tongue.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased secretion from the ipsilateral sublingual gland is a sign of a lesion to the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (CN VII). It would also cause a loss of taste to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Damage to CN X would not affect secretion of salivary glands.

D) CORRECT:

Ipsilateral vocal cord palsy would occur in a lesion of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, which is a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X). Paralysis of the vagus nerve could also lead to loss of the gag reflex, dysphagia, decreased taste from the supraglottic region, as well as ipsilateral paralysis of the soft palate, leading to deviation of the uvula away from the side of the lesion.

Irritation of the auricular branch of the vagus nerve by cerumen or a foreign body is a rare cause of chronic cough. Stimulation of the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (e.g., during otoscopic examination) can result in vasovagal syncope.

E) INCORRECT:

Contralateral (not ipsilateral) deviation of the uvula would be caused by a lesion of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) or the vagus nerve (CN X) due to paralysis of the soft palate. CN IX palsy could also lead to dysphagia, loss of the gag reflex, and sensory loss over the soft palate, upper pharynx, and posterior third of the tongue.

F) INCORRECT:

Ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss would occur from a lesion of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). Such a lesion could also lead to vertigo and horizontal nystagmus. Damage to CN X would not be associated with hearing or vestibular changes.
questions.hint: The posterior external auditory canal is innervated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X). In some individuals, this nerve can trigger an oto-respiratory reflex, causing coughing.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a motorcycle collision. He was not wearing a helmet. Physical examination shows left periorbital ecchymosis. A CT scan of the head shows a fracture of the greater wing of the left sphenoid bone with compression of the left superior orbital fissure. Physical examination of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Complete loss of vision of the left eye

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased sense of smell would be an indication that there is an injury to the olfactory nerve (cranial nerve I). This nerve passes through the cribriform plate so it is vulnerable with fractures of this bone. Pathologies of the superior orbital fissure would not be expected to affect this nerve.

B) INCORRECT:

The sensory innervation of the left cheek is carried out by the maxillary nerve (cranial nerve V2), which exits the cranium via the foramen rotundum. Injury to this nerve would not be expected with a sphenoid bone fracture with compression of the left superior orbital fissure, but rather as a result of an inferior orbital rim or maxillary fracture.

C) INCORRECT:

A fixed, miotic pupil would not be an expected finding in this patient. Fractures impinging on the superior orbital fissure can lead to fixed, dilated pupils as a result of damage to the parasympathetic fibers of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). Miosis is seen in other nervous system conditions such as Horner syndrome and lateral pontine strokes.

D) INCORRECT:

Lateral gaze is achieved via contraction of the lateral rectus muscle. This muscle is innervated by the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI), which passes through the superior orbital fissure. Fractures that impinge on this bony cleft, as in this patient, are likely to interfere with the function of the nerves that pass through. Thus, the expected finding would be abducens nerve palsy and loss of lateral gaze on the left.

E) CORRECT:

The corneal reflex requires uninterrupted signal transmission via the ophthalmic nerve (CN V1). Since this structure passes through the superior orbital fissure, it is likely to be disrupted in this patient with a compressive fracture through the superior orbital fissure. Without the afferent limb of the reflex pathway (cranial nerve V1), there is no motor response (cranial nerve VII).
Image Description:

Frontal view of the left orbit showing the nerves and vessels that enter the orbital cavity.

The common tendinous ring is the origin of all the rectus muscles and of the superior oblique muscle; it encloses all the structures that enter through the optic canal and four of the cranial nerve branches passing through the superior orbital fissure (nasociliary nerve, abducens nerve, and the superior and inferior branch of the oculomotor nerve).

F) INCORRECT:

Complete loss of vision in the left eye would be a result of injury to the optic nerve (cranial nerve II). This nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure, but rather it enters the orbit via the optic canal.
questions.hint: The superior orbital fissure contains CN III, CN IV, CN V1, and CN VI.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful ulcer on his tongue for 3 days. Examination shows a shallow, tender 5-mm wide ulcer on the lateral aspect of the tongue, adjacent to his left first molar. There is no induration surrounding the ulcer or cervical lymphadenopathy. A lesion of the cranial nerve responsible for the transmission of pain from this ulcer would most likely result in which of the following?

choices.text: Decreased sensation in the upper lip
Loss of taste from the supraglottic region

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased sensation in the upper lip would be caused by a lesion of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), not the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.

B) CORRECT:

A lesion of the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) results in difficulty chewing due to paralysis of the muscles of mastication (medial and lateral pterygoid, masseter, temporalis). CN V3 also innervates the mylohyoid muscle, anterior digastric belly, tensor veli palatini, and tensor tympani, and transmits sensory input from the lower third of the face and anterior wall of the external auditory canal. CN V3 is a part of both the afferent and efferent arms of the jaw jerk reflex.

C) INCORRECT:

Loss of taste from the supraglottic region would be caused by a lesion in the vagal nerve, which does not innervate the tongue.

D) INCORRECT:

A diminished gag reflex is caused by a lesion in the vagal nerve or glossopharyngeal nerve. The glossopharyngeal nerve provides taste and somatic sensation to the posterior third of the tongue but not to the anterior two-thirds, where this patient's lesion is located.

E) INCORRECT:

An inability to wrinkle the forehead is seen in facial nerve palsy. The facial nerve transmits taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue via the chorda tympani division but does not transmit somatic sensation (e.g., pain).
Image Description:

The first neuron of the taste pathway is located in the ganglia of the facial, vagus, and glossopharyngeal nerves. The afferent gustatory nerve fibers join to form the nerve tract that projects to the nucleus of the solitary tract.

Second-order neurons project from the medulla oblongata in three distinct branches. Projections to the hypothalamus and amygdala transmit the emotional component of taste perception. Projections to the ventral posterior nucleus (VPM) of the thalamus transmit to the gustatory cortex at the foot of the postcentral gyrus for conscious taste perception.

F) INCORRECT:

Lateral deviation of the tongue is caused by a lesion of the hypoglossal nerve, which innervates the muscles of the tongue. The hypoglossal nerve does not transmit somatic or taste sensation from the tongue.
questions.hint: Since this patient's lesion is located opposite the first molar, it lies anterior to the sulcus terminalis, the structure separating the anterior two-thirds of the tongue from the posterior third. Somatic sensation (e.g., pain) from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is transmitted by the lingual nerve, which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3).

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a 1-year history of left-sided tinnitus is diagnosed with a tumor of the left jugular fossa. Sialometry shows decreased production of saliva from the left parotid gland. The finding on sialometry is best explained by a lesion of the nerve that is also responsible for which of the following?

choices.text: Taste sensation of tip of the tongue
Afferent limb of the gag reflex
Afferent limb of the cough reflex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Protrusion of the tongue is mediated by the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) through the left and right genioglossus muscles. CN XII does not pass through the jugular foramen, but rather through the hypoglossal canal of the occipital bone.

B) INCORRECT:

Taste sensation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is supplied by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (CN VII). Parasympathetic fibers from the chorda tympani also stimulate the sublingual and submandibular salivary glands, but not the parotid. Furthermore, the chorda tympani exits the skull through the petrotympanic fissure, not the jugular foramen.

C) INCORRECT:

Closing of the jaw is mediated by the mandibular nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) that controls the muscles of mastication. The auriculotemporal nerve, which is a branch of the mandibular nerve, carries the parasympathetic fibers of the glossopharyngeal nerve to the parotid gland but neither the trigeminal nerve nor the mandibular nerve carries any parasympathetic fibers. Therefore, an isolated auriculotemporal nerve lesion would decrease parotid gland secretion but it would not affect the muscles of mastication. On the other hand, a lesion of the trigeminal nerve or the mandibular nerve would impair closing of the jaw but it would not decrease parotid gland secretion. Furthermore, the mandibular nerve exits through the foramen ovale, not the jugular foramen.

D) CORRECT:

The afferent sensory limb of the gag reflex is formed by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and the efferent motor limb formed by the vagus nerve (CN X). Upon irritation of the posterior pharyngeal wall, the reflex elicits elevation of the soft palate and bilateral contraction of the pharyngeal muscles.

E) INCORRECT:

The afferent impulses of the cough reflex are carried from the trachea and pharynx along the superior laryngeal nerve, which is a branch of the vagus nerve. Although the vagus nerve does pass through the jugular foramen, neither the vagus nor its branches innervate the parotid gland. The vagus nerve is, instead, responsible for increasing secretion in the gastrointestinal tract (e.g. gastric acid secretion).
Image Description:

Fibers supplying parasympathetic innervation originate in the inferior salivatory nucleus and run with branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) before synapsing in the otic ganglion. Postsynaptic fibers join the auriculotemporal nerve (branch of mandibular nerve, V3) to reach the parotid gland.

Fibers supplying sympathetic innervation originate at spinal segments T1/T2 and join the sympathetic trunk before synapsing with postsynaptic neurons in the superior cervical ganglion. Postsynaptic fibers then reach the parotid gland with branches of the external carotid artery.

Some of the autonomic fibers also run with branches of the parotid plexus of the facial nerve in their further distribution within the gland. While the branches of the facial nerve pass through the parotid gland, sensory innervation is actually supplied by the auriculotemporal nerve.

F) INCORRECT:

The vestibular division of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) carries information from the inner ear to the brain stem. A CN VIII lesion would explain this patient's tinnitus. However, CN VIII travels through the internal acoustic meatus in the temporal bone rather than through the jugular foramen, and a lesion of this nerve would not affect saliva production in the parotid gland.
questions.hint: The most common tumor of the jugular foramen is a paraganglioma (glomus jugulare), which typically presents with pulsatile tinnitus. The parotid gland is innervated by the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which exits the skull at the jugular foramen, posterior to the jugular fossa.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty swallowing and regurgitation of undigested food for the past several months. The patient reports that his symptoms have gotten progressively worse. Physical examination shows severe halitosis and a gurgling sound after he swallows a small amount of water. Results of fluoroscopic barium esophagography are shown. The nerve responsible for motor innervation of the affected muscle is also responsible for which of the following functions?

choices.text: Parasympathetic innervation of the AV node
Sensory innervation of the posterior tongue
Visceral sensory innervation of the carotid sinus
Motor innervation of the ventral tongue
Somatosensory innervation of the semi-circular canals

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The vagus nerve innervates the inferior pharyngeal constrictor, which is the muscle affected in Zenker diverticulum. Parasympathetic fibers that innervate both the SA node (right vagus nerve) and the AV node (left vagus nerve) also originate from the vagus nerve. Additional functions of the vagus nerve include initiation of the cough reflex, innervation of taste receptors of the supraglottis, and innervation of chemo and baroreceptors in the aortic arch.

B) INCORRECT:

The glossopharyngeal nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the posterior tongue. It is also part of the pharyngeal plexus and provides motor innervation to the stylopharyngeus muscle. However, it is not involved in the innervation of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor.

C) INCORRECT:

Branching fibers of the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is located anterior to the internal carotid artery, are responsible for the visceral sensory innervation of the carotid sinus baroreceptors and carotid body chemoreceptors. The glossopharyngeal nerve is part of the pharyngeal plexus and provides motor innervation to the stylopharyngeus muscle but does not innervate the inferior pharyngeal constrictor.

D) INCORRECT:

The hypoglossal nerve is responsible for motor innervation of the tongue and its intrinsic muscles. The hypoglossal nerve is not involved in the innervation of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor.

E) INCORRECT:

The vestibulocochlear nerve is responsible for somatosensory innervation of the semi-circular canals and transmission of equilibrium information from the inner ear to the brain. It does not provide motor innervation to the inferior pharyngeal constrictor.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with a Zenker diverticulum, which is an outpouching of the esophagus between two parts of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor (Killian triangle). The inferior pharyngeal constrictor is innervated by branches from the pharyngeal plexus of the vagus nerve.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being hit in the head with a baseball bat. Physical examination shows swelling and bruising around the left temple and eye. A CT scan of the head shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone and blood in the sphenoid sinus. Neurological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Inward deviation of the left eye
Decreased hearing in the left ear
Deviation of uvula to the right

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left homonymous hemianopia would be seen with damage to the visual pathways at the level of the right occipital lobe (e.g., due to right posterior cerebral artery stroke). This young patient does not have any known risk factors for CVA and given the mechanism of injury and imaging findings, a different finding is more likely.

Severe head trauma can result in a skull base fracture extending through the floor of the sella turcica and sphenoid sinus to injure the crossing fibers at the optic chiasm, which would cause a bitemporal hemianopia.

B) CORRECT:

Inward deviation of the eye (esotropia) can result from fractures of the sphenoid bone that extend anteriorly through the superior orbital fissure to damage the abducens nerve (CN VI). Other nerves that can be injured in skull base fractures involving the superior orbital fissure are the oculomotor nerve (ptosis with a fixed and dilated pupil), trochlear nerve (ocular extorsion and vertical diplopia), and ophthalmic nerve (absent corneal reflex). CN VI palsy is the most common cranial nerve palsy because of the long and tortuous route that CN VI takes intracranially, along which the nerve is vulnerable to injury by trauma (as in this patient), neoplasms (e.g., sphenoid ridge meningiomas), increased ICP (e.g., pseudotumor cerebri, SAH), neurovascular pathologies (e.g., cavernous sinus thrombosis, carotid-cavernous fistulas), and infection (e.g., syphilis).
Image Description:

Superior view of internal surface

C) INCORRECT:

Left facial paralysis would indicate facial nerve palsy. The facial nerve (CN VII) is commonly injured in fractures of the petrous part of the temporal bone (e.g., transverse temporal bone fractures) that extend from the internal acoustic meatus to the stylomastoid foramen. Although this patient has bruising around his left temple, his CT scan shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone, for which left facial paralysis is not typical.
Image Description:

Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased hearing in the left ear would suggest vestibulocochlear nerve injury, which can result from skull base fractures extending from the petrous pyramid of the temporal bone into the internal acoustic meatus. Other typical findings associated with this type of injury include signs of fluid accumulation in the middle ear, CSF otorrhea, hemotympanum, and mastoid ecchymosis. Vertigo and horizontal nystagmus may be present as well. This patient's CT scan shows a fracture through the sphenoid bone rather than the temporal bone, making this finding unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Deviation of the uvula to the right would be consistent with a left vagus nerve palsy. CN X can be injured in posterior cranial fossa fractures that extend into the jugular foramen., which is located between the temporal bone and occipital bone. However, this patient's CT scan shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone.
questions.hint: Blood in the sphenoid sinus and a transverse fracture on imaging are indicative of an anterior fracture of the middle cranial fossa. Anterior middle cranial fossa fractures may involve the orbital apex, superior orbital fissure, and clinoid processes.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after collapsing on the street. On arrival, he is obtunded. His pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 250/120 mm Hg. A CT scan of the head shows an intracerebral hemorrhage involving bilateral thalamic nuclei and the third ventricle. Cortical detection of which of the following types of stimuli is most likely to remain unaffected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Facial fine touch is conveyed via the ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus, the relay center for the trigeminal nerve pathway. The ventral posteromedial nucleus receives afferent input from the trigeminal nucleus and projects to the primary somatosensory cortex. Hence, a bilateral thalamic lesion would affect facial fine touch.

B) INCORRECT:

Gustatory information is conveyed via the ventral posteromedial nucleus, the thalamic relay center for taste. The ventral posterior medial nucleus receives afferent input from the trigeminal nucleus and projects to the primary somatosensory cortex. Hence, a bilateral thalamic lesion would affect taste.

C) INCORRECT:

Visual information is conveyed via the lateral geniculate body, the thalamic relay center for the optic pathway. The lateral geniculate body receives afferent input from optic nerve via the superior colliculus and projects to the primary visual cortex. Therefore, a bilateral thalamic lesion would affect vision.

D) INCORRECT:

Auditory information is conveyed via the medial geniculate nucleus, the thalamic relay center for the auditory pathway. The medial geniculate nucleus receives afferent input from the inferior colliculus and the superior olivary nucleus and projects to the primary auditory cortex. Therefore, a bilateral thalamic lesion would affect auditory sensation.

E) CORRECT:

The olfactory bulb is the first central relay station for the olfactory pathway, which processes odor information. It receives afferent input from the olfactory nerve and projects to the primary olfactory cortex. Although the olfactory sensory neurons do not project directly to the thalamus, the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus receives and sends information to the olfactory cortex. Damage to the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus does not impair cortical olfactory detection (which would result in anosmia), but it does impair other olfactory functions, such as olfactory identification or discrimination (which may result in dysosmia).

Olfactory dysfunction is a common finding on neurologic examination in patients with Alzheimer disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Proprioception is conveyed by the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus, the relay center for the dorsal columns. The ventral posterolateral nucleus receives afferent input from the gray matter of the spinal cord via the dorsal columns and projects to the primary somatosensory cortex. Therefore, a bilateral thalamic lesion would affect proprioception.
questions.hint: With the exception of one pathway, all sensory information pathways are relayed by thalamic neurons before reaching functionally distinct areas of the cortex. The pathway in question projects to the cortical area that is often the first to be affected in patients with Alzheimer disease.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressively worsening headaches and fatigue. She has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss in the same time period. MRI of the head shows a hyperintense mass with extension into the right foramen rotundum. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Decreased sensation over the cheekbone, nasolabial fold, and the upper lip
Hemiatrophy of the tongue with right-sided deviation when protruded
Abnormal taste of the distal tongue and decreased sensation behind the ear
Absent corneal reflex and decreased sensation of the forehead
Masseter and temporalis muscle wasting with jaw deviation to the right

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Sensation to the middle third of the face (i.e., cheekbone, nasolabial fold, and upper lip) is supplied by the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2). After exiting the skull through the foramen rotundum, CN V2 passes through the infraorbital canal to exit the orbit via the infraorbital foramen and then divides into the cutaneous branches, which supply sensation to the midface. A mass extending into the right foramen rotundum, as seen in this patient's MRI, could compress CN V2, resulting in anesthesia of the midface.
Image Description:

Superior view of internal surface

B) INCORRECT:

Hemiatrophy of the tongue with right-sided deviation when protruded would indicate damage to the right hypoglossal nerve, which supplies motor innervation to the tongue. However, the hypoglossal nerve exits the skull through the hypoglossal foramen, whereas this patient's MRI shows a mass extending into the foramen rotundum.

C) INCORRECT:

Abnormal taste of the distal tongue and decreased sensation behind the ear would indicate facial nerve palsy. The facial nerve (CN VII) supplies taste sensation to the anterior 2/3 of the tongue and cutaneous sensation posterior to the ear. However, the facial nerve passes through the internal acoustic meatus and partly exits the skull through the stylomastoid foramen, whereas this patient's MRI shows a mass extending into the foramen rotundum.

D) INCORRECT:

An absent corneal reflex and decreased sensation of the forehead would indicate damage to the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V1), which mediates the afferent limb of the corneal reflex and supplies sensation to the superior third of the face. However, CN V1 passes through the superior orbital fissure, whereas this patient's MRI shows a mass extending into the foramen rotundum.

The efferent limb of the corneal reflex is mediated by the facial nerve (CN VII).
Image Description:

Frontal view of the left orbit showing the nerves and vessels that enter the orbital cavity.

The common tendinous ring is the origin of all the rectus muscles and of the superior oblique muscle; it encloses all the structures that enter through the optic canal and four of the cranial nerve branches passing through the superior orbital fissure (nasociliary nerve, abducens nerve, and the superior and inferior branch of the oculomotor nerve).

E) INCORRECT:

Masseter and temporalis muscle wasting with jaw deviation to the right would indicate damage to the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), which supplies the masseter, temporalis, and other muscles of mastication. Paralysis of the CN V3 causes deviation of the jaw toward the injured side. However, CN V3 exits the skull through the foramen ovale (skull), whereas this patient's MRI shows a mass extending into the foramen rotundum.
questions.hint: The maxillary nerve passes through the foramen rotundum.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. During the last 6 months, he has had recurring pneumonia after undergoing a surgical operation. He reports that, when food has gone down his windpipe, he has not automatically coughed. Examination shows normal voluntary coughing, but an impaired cough reflex. The nerve responsible for this patient's symptoms is most likely damaged at which of the following anatomical sites?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Through the infratemporal fossa runs the mandibular nerve (CN V3), the third branch of the trigeminal nerve. Injury to CN V3 can lead to weakness of the mastication muscles as well as hyperesthesias of the chin, lower lip, and inside of the cheek. However, this nerve is not responsible for the absent laryngeal cough reflex seen in this patient, and the internal laryngeal nerve does not pass through the infratemporal fossa.

B) INCORRECT:

Through the foramen magnum travels the accessory nerve (CN XI), which innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Injury to CN XI would result in weakness of head-turning (contralateral side) and shoulder elevation (ipsilateral side). This nerve is not responsible for the absent laryngeal cough reflex seen in this patient, and the internal laryngeal nerve does not pass through the foramen magnum.

C) INCORRECT:

Under the aortic arch travels the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X). Recurrent laryngeal nerve dysfunction can lead to hoarseness or dyspnea (due to paralysis of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, which opens the vocal cords). However, this nerve is not responsible for the absent laryngeal cough reflex seen in this patient, and the internal laryngeal nerve does not pass through the aortic arch.

D) CORRECT:

The superior laryngeal nerve divides into an internal and external branch beneath the internal carotid artery. The internal laryngeal nerve runs directly beneath the mucosa of the piriform recess, along with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and is distributed to the mucous membrane of the larynx. The internal laryngeal nerve can be injured during surgery (e.g., thyroidectomy) or damaged by food items (e.g., a fishbone) being trapped in the piriform fossa. Damage to this nerve classically manifests with an impaired cough reflex, which increases the risk for recurrent aspiration pneumonia.

E) INCORRECT:

Through the parotid gland runs the facial nerve (CN VII), which is commonly injured during parotid resections or oncologic procedures (e.g., vestibular schwannoma surgery). Injury to CN VII can lead to the ipsilateral loss of facial expression, impaired function of the submandibular, sublingual, and lacrimal glands, hyperacusis, and impaired taste perception of the anterior ⅔ of the tongue. However, this nerve is not responsible for the absent laryngeal cough reflex seen in this patient, and the internal laryngeal nerve does not pass through the parotid gland.
questions.hint: An intact cough reflex depends primarily on afferent fibers of the internal laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve), which transmit sensations of the larynx above the vocal cords, and on efferent fibers of the vagus, phrenic, and spinal motor nerves. This patient is able to cough voluntarily (indicating an intact efferent pathway) but has an impaired cough reflex (indicating a defect in the afferent pathway).

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife after the sudden onset of dizziness, nausea, and left-sided weakness. His blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows decreased muscle tone and hyperreflexia in the right upper and lower extremities. His gait is unsteady, and he falls to the left when attempting to walk. Finger-to-nose testing shows dysmetria on the left side. A CT scan of the head shows a small lesion in the left lateral pons that involves the nucleus of a cranial nerve that exits the brain at the middle cerebellar peduncle. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Ptosis and inability to look up with the right eye
Hoarseness and deviation of the uvula to the right
Deviation of the tongue to the left when protruded
Winging of the left scapula and weakness turning the head to the right
Impaired vision and absent direct pupillary light reflex of the left eye
Difficulty chewing and deviation of the jaw to the left
Inability to smell vanilla or coffee

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ptosis (due to weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle) and the inability to look up (due to weakness of the superior rectus muscle) can occur in patients who have a lesion of the oculomotor nerve (CN III). This nerve arises from the midbrain and would not be affected by a pontine lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

Hoarseness and deviation of the uvula to the right can occur in patients who have a lesion of the left vagus nerve (CN X). This nerve arises from the medulla and would not be affected by a pontine lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Deviation of the tongue to the left when protruded can occur in patients who have a lesion of the left hypoglossal nerve (CN XII). This nerve arises from the medulla and would not be affected by a pontine lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Winging of the scapula and weakness turning the head to the right are caused by weakness of the left sternocleidomastoid muscle, which can occur in patients who have a lesion of the left spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). This nerve arises from the upper cervical spine (C1–C5) and would not be affected by a pontine lesion.
Image Description:

Ventral view

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired vision and absent direct pupillary light reflex of the left eye can occur in patients who have a lesion of the left optic nerve (CN II), which transmits visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm, from which it continues on in the optic tract. The optic nerve and its continuations arise directly from the forebrain and would not be affected by a pontine lesion.

F) CORRECT:

The trigeminal nerve (CN V) exits the brain at the middle cerebellar peduncle, and its motor nucleus is located in the lateral portion of the upper pons. This patient has an infarct of the left lateral pons that involves this nucleus. As a result, the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), which innervates the muscles of mastication (e.g., the lateral pterygoid muscle), could be affected and result in difficulty chewing and ipsilateral deviation of the jaw.

A lesion of the left lateral pons can also affect the nuclei of the facial nerve (CN VII) and vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). Therefore, patients with lateral pontine syndrome can also develop ipsilateral facial paralysis (CN VII) and ipsilateral hearing loss, vertigo, and nystagmus (CN VIII). The nucleus of the abducens nerve (CN VI) is located in the medial portion of the pons and is therefore not typically affected in individuals with lateral pontine syndrome.
Image Description:

Sagittal section of the brainstem

G) INCORRECT:

The inability to smell vanilla or coffee suggests a lesion of the olfactory nerve (CN I). This nerve arises directly from the forebrain and would not be affected by a pontine lesion.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral limb ataxia) and imaging findings indicate a diagnosis of lateral pontine syndrome. The trigeminal nerve (CN V) exits the brainstem on the anterior aspect of the pons at the middle cerebellar peduncle.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He does not open his eyes on command or respond to verbal cues. A CT scan of the head shows a hyperdense fluid collection in the right medial temporal lobe with medial displacement of the uncus and parahippocampal gyrus of the temporal lobe. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely to be injured as a result of this patient's lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The facial nerve (CN VII) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VII is in close proximity to the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and it can be injured by bleeds or aneurysms of this vessel.

B) INCORRECT:

The vagus nerve (CN X) exits the brainstem at the medulla, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN X can be injured by direct neck trauma. Injury to this nerve can also occur because of compression by an aortic aneurysm.

C) INCORRECT:

The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VIII is in close proximity to the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and it can be injured by bleeds or aneurysms of this vessel.

D) INCORRECT:

The abducens nerve (CN VI) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VI is local to the basilar artery, and it can be injured by a basilar artery aneurysm.

E) CORRECT:

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is most likely to be injured by uncal herniation, which manifests with an abducted and depressed ipsilateral eye (due to damage to motor fibers that innervate most of the extraocular eye muscles) with a fixed, dilated pupil (due to damage to parasympathetic fibers). Other features of uncal herniation include cortical blindness with contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing due to compression of the posterior cerebral artery, and Kernohan phenomenon due to compression of the contralateral cerebral peduncle. A downward shift of the brainstem causes hemorrhages and compression of the reticular formation, which can lead to impaired consciousness and, ultimately, death.

A CN III injury can also be caused by an aneurysm or bleed of the posterior communicating artery or posterior cerebral artery, both of which are in close proximity to this nerve.
Image Description:

Brain herniations occur as a result of increased intracranial pressure, such as that caused by subdural hematomas. Variations include herniation of brain tissue under the falx cerebri (1), below the tentorium cerebelli (2, 3), downwards through the foramen magnum (4), above the tentorium cerebelli (5), or outside of the skull (6).

F) INCORRECT:

The trigeminal nerve (CN V) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN V can be injured by a lateral pontine lesion. Injury to this nerve can also occur because of compression by a superior cerebellar artery aneurysm.
questions.hint: The findings from this patient's radiological imaging indicate a transtentorial uncal herniation.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man presents with poor vision in his right eye that has slowly worsened during the past year. On examination, visual acuity is 20/100 in the right eye and 20/30 in the left eye, compared with 20/30 in each eye 3 years ago. The right pupil is 5 mm in diameter and minimally reactive. The left pupil is 4 mm in diameter and reactive. An afferent pupillary defect is detected in the right eye. Fundus examination reveals a pale right optic nerve and a pink left optic nerve; no cupping is present.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Order treponemal antibody and HIV testing
Measure serum erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein level, and platelet count
Perform MRI of the brain and orbits

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optic atrophy may also be seen after cases of optic neuritis. Optic neuritis tends to manifest with painful vision loss that progresses acutely over hours to days in one eye. Optic neuritis is associated with multiple sclerosis, although it can also be caused by other inflammatory or infectious conditions. Lumbar puncture or testing for syphilis and HIV infection may be appropriate in certain cases if an inflammatory or infectious cause is suspected. In this case, given the subacute to chronic progression, lack of pain, and absence of other findings suggestive of these etiologies, a compressive lesion is more likely, and lumbar puncture is therefore not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Optic atrophy may also be seen after cases of optic neuritis. Optic neuritis tends to manifest with painful vision loss that progresses acutely over hours to days in one eye. Optic neuritis is associated with multiple sclerosis, although it can also be caused by other inflammatory or infectious conditions. Lumbar puncture or testing for syphilis and HIV infection may be appropriate in certain cases if an inflammatory or infectious cause is suspected. In this case, given the subacute to chronic progression, lack of pain, and absence of other findings suggestive of these etiologies, a compressive lesion is more likely, and lumbar puncture is therefore not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein level, and platelet count is indicated when giant-cell arteritis is suspected. Giant-cell arteritis manifests acutely in individuals older than 50 years of age and is usually associated with acute unilateral vision loss, headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest radiography also has a low yield in identifying causes of optic atrophy and is therefore also not a first-line test in cases of isolated optic atrophy.

E) CORRECT:

An afferent pupillary defect (a reduced pupillary response to light shone in the affected eye) suggests dysfunction of the optic nerve, and a pale optic nerve is a sign of optic atrophy. Optic atrophy has many causes, and a careful history and examination are critical to narrowing the differential diagnosis. In a young patient with subacute to chronic vision loss and no significant medical history, a compressive lesion, such as an optic-nerve meningioma or glioma, must be ruled out as a cause of optic atrophy. MRI of the brain and orbit, with fat suppression and contrast, can identify compressive lesions along the optic nerve.

Key learning point: Optic atrophy should be suspected in a patient who presents with subacute to chronic vision loss and a pale optic nerve, and an MRI of the orbit and brain should be performed to rule out an optic-nerve lesion.

questions.text: One week after being involved in a bicycling accident, a 32-year-old woman comes to the office because of intermittent double vision. She reports worsening of symptoms when she tries to type on her computer or while buttoning her shirts. Physical examination shows a slight right-sided head tilt. Her left eye is deviated upwards, which becomes even more prominent when she attempts left eye adduction. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to impaired innervation to which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The superior oblique muscle is innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV) and is responsible for abduction, internal rotation (incyclotorsion), and depression of the eye during adduction. Impairment of this muscle manifests with vertical and torsional diplopia that worsens when the patient looks down and toward the nose (e.g., while typing on a computer); expected examination findings include external rotation (excyclotorsion), and upward deviation (hypertropia) of the affected eye. Downward gaze is impaired when the affected eye is adducted. The contralateral head tilt in this patient may be conscious or unconscious and serves as a compensatory mechanism.
Image Description:

Trochlear nerve palsy (here of the left eye) causes paralysis of the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle. This leads to hypertropia (upwards deviation) that increases in adduction, excyclotorsion (outward rotation) of the affected eye and slight limitation of abduction. The findings may be discrete.

Patients typically present with vertical or oblique diplopia. Hypertropia and diplopia usually increases with ipsilateral head-tilt and decreases with contralateral head-tilt. Patients may adopt the latter as a compensatory posture (upper right of image).

B) INCORRECT:

The medial rectus muscle is responsible for adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause horizontal diplopia, limitation of the ipsilateral eye to the medial gaze, and deviation of the eye outwards (exotropia).

C) INCORRECT:

The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for abduction of the eye and is innervated by the abducens nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause medial deviation of the eye (esotropia) at primary gaze, an ipsilateral abduction deficit, and horizontal diplopia that worsens when looking at distant objects.
Image Description:

Abducens nerve palsy (here of the left eye) impairs the function of the lateral rectus muscle. This causes esotropia (medial deviation) of the affected eye and limits its abduction. Patients present with horizontal diplopia that worsens when turning the gaze to the affected side or looking at distant objects.

D) INCORRECT:

The inferior oblique muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve and is responsible for excyclotorsion, elevation, and abduction of the eye. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause the eye to deviate downwards (hypotropia) and rotate inwards (incyclotorsion).
Image Description:

Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

E) INCORRECT:

The inferior rectus muscle is responsible for depression, excyclotorsion, and adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause vertical diplopia, limitation of downgaze in the ipsilateral eye, and upward eye deviation (hypertropia).
questions.hint: This patient's right-sided head tilt, diplopia, upward deviation of the eye that worsens during adduction, and history of blunt trauma to the head suggest palsy of the left trochlear nerve (CN IV).

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He does not open his eyes on command or respond to verbal cues. A CT scan of the head shows a hyperdense fluid collection in the right medial temporal lobe with medial and downward displacement of the uncus. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely to be injured as a result of this patient's lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The facial nerve (CN VII) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VII is in close proximity to the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and it can be injured by bleeds or aneurysms of this vessel.

B) INCORRECT:

The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VIII is in close proximity to the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and it can be injured by bleeds or aneurysms of this vessel.

C) INCORRECT:

The abducens nerve (CN VI) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VI is local to the basilar artery, and it can be injured by a basilar artery aneurysm.

D) CORRECT:

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is most likely to be injured by uncal herniation, which manifests with an abducted and depressed ipsilateral eye (due to damage to motor fibers that innervate most of the extraocular eye muscles) with a fixed, dilated pupil (due to damage to parasympathetic fibers). Other features of uncal herniation include cortical blindness with contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing due to compression of the posterior cerebral artery, and Kernohan phenomenon due to compression of the contralateral cerebral peduncle. A downward shift of the brainstem causes hemorrhages and compression of the reticular formation, which can lead to impaired consciousness and, ultimately, death.

A CN III injury can also be caused by an aneurysm or bleed of the posterior communicating artery or posterior cerebral artery, both of which are in close proximity to this nerve.
Image Description:

Brain herniations occur as a result of increased intracranial pressure, such as that caused by subdural hematomas. Variations include herniation of brain tissue under the falx cerebri (1), below the tentorium cerebelli (2, 3), downwards through the foramen magnum (4), above the tentorium cerebelli (5), or outside of the skull (6).

E) INCORRECT:

The trigeminal nerve (CN V) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN V can be injured by a lateral pontine lesion. Injury to this nerve can also occur because of compression by a superior cerebellar artery aneurysm.
questions.hint: The findings from this patient's radiological imaging indicate a transtentorial uncal herniation.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most likely in a patient with a lesion affecting the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3)?

choices.text: Decreased sensation in the upper lip
Loss of taste from the supraglottic region

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased sensation in the upper lip would be caused by a lesion of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), not the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.

B) CORRECT:

A lesion of the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) results in difficulty chewing due to paralysis of the muscles of mastication (medial and lateral pterygoid, masseter, temporalis). CN V3 also innervates the mylohyoid muscle, anterior digastric belly, tensor veli palatini, and tensor tympani, and transmits sensory input from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, lower third of the face and anterior wall of the external auditory canal. CN V3 is a part of both the afferent and efferent arms of the jaw jerk reflex.

C) INCORRECT:

Loss of taste from the supraglottic region is caused by a lesion in the vagal nerve.

D) INCORRECT:

A diminished gag reflex is caused by a lesion in the vagal nerve or glossopharyngeal nerve.

E) INCORRECT:

Lateral deviation of the tongue is caused by a lesion of the hypoglossal nerve, which innervates the muscles of the tongue.

questions.text: One week after a bicycling accident, a 32-year-old woman comes to your clinic with intermittent double vision. She reports that her symptoms worsen when she types on her computer or buttons her shirts. On examination, she has a slight right-sided head tilt. Her left eye is deviated upwards, and this deviation becomes more pronounced when she attempts left eye adduction. Which one of the following muscles is most likely affected due to impaired innervation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The inferior rectus muscle is responsible for depression, excyclotorsion, and adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause vertical diplopia, limitation of downgaze in the ipsilateral eye, and upward eye deviation (hypertropia).

B) INCORRECT:

The inferior oblique muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve and is responsible for excyclotorsion, elevation, and abduction of the eye. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause the eye to deviate downwards (hypotropia) and rotate inwards (incyclotorsion).

C) INCORRECT:

The medial rectus muscle is responsible for adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause horizontal diplopia, limitation of the ipsilateral eye to the medial gaze, and deviation of the eye outwards (exotropia).

D) INCORRECT:

The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for abduction of the eye and is innervated by the abducens nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause medial deviation of the eye (esotropia) at primary gaze, an ipsilateral abduction deficit, and horizontal diplopia that worsens when looking at distant objects.

E) CORRECT:

The superior oblique muscle is innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV) and is responsible for abduction, internal rotation (incyclotorsion), and depression of the eye during adduction. Impairment of this muscle manifests with vertical and torsional diplopia that worsens when the patient looks down and toward the nose (e.g., while typing on a computer); expected examination findings include external rotation (excyclotorsion), and upward deviation (hypertropia) of the affected eye. Downward gaze is impaired when the affected eye is adducted. The contralateral head tilt in this patient may be conscious or unconscious and serves as a compensatory mechanism.

Key learning point: Trochlear nerve palsy impairs the superior oblique muscle, causing vertical and torsional diplopia that worsens with downward and inward gaze.
Image Description:

Trochlear nerve palsy (here of the left eye) causes paralysis of the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle. This leads to hypertropia (upwards deviation) that increases in adduction, excyclotorsion (outward rotation) of the affected eye and slight limitation of abduction. The findings may be discrete.

Patients typically present with vertical or oblique diplopia. Hypertropia and diplopia usually increases with ipsilateral head-tilt and decreases with contralateral head-tilt. Patients may adopt the latter as a compensatory posture (upper right of image).
questions.hint: This patient's right-sided head tilt, diplopia, upward deviation of the eye that worsens during adduction, and history of blunt trauma to the head suggest palsy of the left trochlear nerve (CN IV).

questions.text: You are caring for a 26-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by ambulance following a motor vehicle collision. He does not open his eyes to command or respond to verbal cues. A CT scan of the head reveals a hyperdense fluid collection in the right medial temporal lobe with medial and downward displacement of the uncus. Which one of the following cranial nerves is most likely to be injured as a result of this lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The facial nerve (CN VII) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VII is in close proximity to the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and it can be injured by bleeds or aneurysms of this vessel.

B) CORRECT:

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is most likely to be injured by uncal herniation, which manifests with an abducted and depressed ipsilateral eye (due to damage to motor fibers that innervate most of the extraocular eye muscles) with a fixed, dilated pupil (due to damage to parasympathetic fibers). Other features of uncal herniation include cortical blindness with contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing due to compression of the posterior cerebral artery, and Kernohan phenomenon due to compression of the contralateral cerebral peduncle. A downward shift of the brainstem causes hemorrhages and compression of the reticular formation, which can lead to impaired consciousness and, ultimately, death.

A CN III injury can also be caused by an aneurysm or bleed of the posterior communicating artery or posterior cerebral artery, both of which are in close proximity to this nerve.

Key learning point: Transtentorial uncal herniation most commonly compresses the oculomotor nerve (CN III), leading to a fixed, dilated pupil and impaired eye movements.
Image Description:

Brain herniations occur as a result of increased intracranial pressure, such as that caused by subdural hematomas. Variations include herniation of brain tissue under the falx cerebri (1), below the tentorium cerebelli (2, 3), downwards through the foramen magnum (4), above the tentorium cerebelli (5), or outside of the skull (6).

C) INCORRECT:

The abducens nerve (CN VI) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VI is local to the basilar artery, and it can be injured by a basilar artery aneurysm.

D) INCORRECT:

The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VIII is in close proximity to the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and it can be injured by bleeds or aneurysms of this vessel.

E) INCORRECT:

The trigeminal nerve (CN V) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN V can be injured by a lateral pontine lesion. Injury to this nerve can also occur because of compression by a superior cerebellar artery aneurysm.
questions.hint: The findings from this patient's radiological imaging indicate a transtentorial uncal herniation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to your clinic with worsening double vision and drooping of the right eyelid for 2 days. He also reports frequent headaches over the past month. On examination, the right eye is deviated laterally and inferiorly at rest. The right pupil is dilated and does not react to light or accommodation. His diplopia improves slightly when looking to the right. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery can cause compression of the nearby oculomotor nerve (CN III). Compressive lesions are characterized by pupillary involvement due to injury to the outer parasympathetic layer of CN III (which controls pupil dilation, light reactivity, and accommodation). Additional injury to the deeper somatic fibers of the nerve (which control extraocular muscles) is responsible for this patient's ptosis and “down and out” gaze.

Acute CN III palsy due to a cerebral aneurysm is very concerning for imminent rupture. A patient presenting with dilated pupils and a history of recent headaches should undergo an urgent MRI with MR angiography.
