Key learning point: Oculomotor nerve palsy with pupil involvement and "down and out" eye deviation is most commonly caused by compression from a posterior communicating artery aneurysm.
Image Description:

Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

B) INCORRECT:

Enlarging pituitary adenomas typically present with bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the optic chiasm. Sufficiently large adenomas can cause headaches and CN III palsy due to compression resulting from lateral extension of the tumor. However, a tumor at the optic chiasm is unlikely to cause an isolated CN III palsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), when present bilaterally, is often a sign of multiple sclerosis. Lesions in the MLF cause horizontal diplopia and impaired adduction on lateral gaze in one eye, with nystagmus in the contralateral abducting eye. However, this patient does not have nystagmus and the diplopia in INO is only present when the patient's gaze moves towards the contralateral side of the lesion, in contrast to this patient's resting diplopia. Moreover, INO would not explain this patient's eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, or the dilated pupil.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus has a highly variable clinical manifestation because of the number of cranial nerves passing through the region (CN III, IV, V1, V2, VI). Patients with cavernous sinus thrombosis can present with headaches and unilateral CN III palsy. However, this patient does not have the typical signs of fever, unilateral periorbital edema, photophobia, and chemosis seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis. Moreover, isolated involvement of CN III without damage to any of the other cranial nerves that pass through the cavernous sinus would be uncommon.
questions.hint: Double vision, eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, and a dilated pupil that does not react to light point to oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy, with both somatic and parasympathetic involvement.

questions.text: Which one of the following findings is most likely to be present in a patient with a lesion affecting the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3)?

choices.text: Loss of taste from the supraglottic region.
Decreased sensation in the upper lip.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Loss of taste from the supraglottic region is caused by a lesion in the vagal nerve.

B) INCORRECT:

A diminished gag reflex is caused by a lesion in the vagal nerve or glossopharyngeal nerve.

C) INCORRECT:

Lateral deviation of the tongue is caused by a lesion of the hypoglossal nerve, which innervates the muscles of the tongue.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased sensation in the upper lip would be caused by a lesion of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), not the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.

E) CORRECT:

A lesion of the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) results in difficulty chewing due to paralysis of the muscles of mastication (medial and lateral pterygoid, masseter, temporalis). CN V3 also innervates the mylohyoid muscle, anterior digastric belly, tensor veli palatini, and tensor tympani, and transmits sensory input from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, lower third of the face and anterior wall of the external auditory canal. CN V3 is a part of both the afferent and efferent arms of the jaw jerk reflex.

Key learning point: The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) controls the muscles of mastication, so its lesion causes difficulty chewing.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with diabetes and hypertension presents with acute onset diplopia and left eyelid drooping that began 2 hours ago. He denies headache or neck stiffness. Examination shows left eye ptosis with a down-and-out gaze deviation. The left pupil is 4 mm and reactive to light, while the right pupil is 3 mm and reactive. Visual acuity is normal bilaterally. The remainder of the neurological examination is normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT angiography of the head and neck
Assessment of cardiovascular risk factors and neurology referral

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is appropriate if MRI with MR angiography is not available and compression is suspected. This patient's pupillary sparing in combination with diabetes suggests an ischemic rather than compressive etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI with MR angiography is indicated if there is pupillary involvement or incomplete palsy regardless of pupillary findings, as these suggest compressive lesions. This patient has complete motor palsy with pupillary sparing, which is characteristic of ischemic microangiopathy rather than compression.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is performed to investigate for demyelinating disease if MRI is normal in cases of suspected compressive lesions; it is not appropriate for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Urgent neurosurgical consultation is indicated for compressive lesions such as posterior communicating artery aneurysms, which typically manifest with pupillary involvement and headache. This patient's pupillary sparing and lack of headache make compression unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Complete oculomotor palsy with normal pupillary reflex (pupillary sparing) in a patient aged over 50 years with atherosclerotic risk factors suggests ischemic microangiopathy. Initial neuroimaging is not routinely required for this presentation. Management includes assessing cardiovascular risk factors and consulting neurology, as ischemic cranial nerve III palsy typically resolves spontaneously within 6–8 weeks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of horizontal diplopia that worsens when looking at distant objects. She reports difficulty looking to the left. Physical examination shows esotropia of the left eye and inability to abduct the left eye. She has no medical history and takes no medications. Vital signs are BP, 118/76; blood glucose is 94 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Assess erythrocyte sedimentation rate and lipid profile
MRI head and orbits with IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While neurology consultation is appropriate, observation alone without imaging is insufficient for patients under 50 years of age without ischemic risk factors. Neuroimaging should be performed to rule out structural causes before considering a watchful waiting approach.

B) INCORRECT:

Ophthalmology consultation for prism glasses addresses symptom management but does not evaluate the underlying cause. Initial workup should focus on determining the etiology before considering symptomatic treatment options.

C) INCORRECT:

Assessment of ischemic risk factors, such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate and lipid profile, is appropriate for older patients or those with established risk factors. However, in a younger patient without ischemic risk factors, neuroimaging takes priority to exclude structural causes.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- MRI head and orbits with IV contrast is indicated for patients under 50 years of age with abducens nerve palsy, particularly if there are no ischemic risk factors. This imaging evaluates for structural causes, including tumors, aneurysms, and other space-occupying lesions that may compress the sixth cranial nerve.

E) INCORRECT:

CT head without contrast is not the preferred imaging modality for evaluating cranial nerve palsies. While CT with contrast may be useful for bony lesions or trauma, MRI with contrast provides superior visualization of cranial nerves and soft tissue abnormalities.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with no significant medical history presents with a 6-hour history of worsening diplopia and right-sided headache. She says that the diplopia began gradually this morning and has progressively worsened. Physical examination shows mild right ptosis, inability to adduct the right eye, and a 6-mm right pupil that is minimally reactive to light. The left pupil is 3 mm and briskly reactive. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Check blood glucose and arrange neurology follow-up
Obtain urgent MRI head with MR angiography
Refer to ophthalmology for prism glasses

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This approach is appropriate for complete oculomotor palsy with pupillary sparing in patients aged over 50 years with atherosclerotic risk factors, suggesting ischemic microangiopathy. However, any pupillary involvement indicates potential compression requiring urgent evaluation regardless of completeness of the palsy.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with incomplete oculomotor nerve palsy with pupillary involvement, which suggests a compressive lesion such as a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Incomplete palsy regardless of pupillary findings requires urgent MRI head with MR angiography to evaluate for compressive lesions, particularly aneurysms.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is only considered if MRI is normal, because it is used to evaluate for oligoclonal bands or albuminocytologic dissociation, which helps in the investigation of demyelinating disease.

D) INCORRECT:

CT head without contrast is insufficient for evaluating cranial nerve palsies. MRI with contrast is the preferred imaging modality for direct visualization of the nerve, and MR angiography is specifically needed to evaluate for aneurysms in oculomotor nerve palsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic treatment with prism glasses is inappropriate until the underlying cause is identified and treated. Pupillary involvement requires immediate evaluation for compressive lesions that may require neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden, severe right-sided headache and double vision that began 4 hours ago. She describes the headache as being located behind her right eye. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On examination, her right eyelid is drooping, and her right eye is deviated inferiorly and laterally. The right pupil is 6 mm and poorly reactive to light, while the left pupil is 3 mm and briskly reactive. Extraocular movements are restricted in all directions of gaze except for abduction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ophthalmoplegic migraine is a rare syndrome of recurrent headaches associated with cranial nerve palsies, most commonly affecting the oculomotor nerve (CN III). However, this is a diagnosis of exclusion, typically seen in younger patients with a history of similar episodes. In an older patient with vascular risk factors who presents with a first-time, painful, pupil-involving CN III palsy, a life-threatening vascular cause must be presumed until proven otherwise.

B) INCORRECT:

Pituitary apoplexy, or hemorrhage into a pituitary adenoma, can manifest with a sudden severe headache and ophthalmoplegia from compression of adjacent structures such as the cavernous sinus. However, it often causes bitemporal hemianopsia from optic chiasm compression and typically affects multiple cranial nerves (e.g., III, IV, and VI) rather than an isolated oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with a classic compressive oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy, characterized by ptosis (levator palpebrae superioris paralysis), a 'down and out' eye position (unopposed action of cranial nerve IV and cranial nerve VI), and a fixed, dilated pupil (mydriasis). The parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction travel on the superficial aspect of CN III, making them vulnerable to external compression. An expanding or ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm is the most common cause of this presentation because of its anatomical proximity to CN III. The sudden, severe headache is highly concerning for an aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage, a neurosurgical emergency that requires immediate investigation with CT angiography.

D) INCORRECT:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis can cause headache, ptosis, and ophthalmoplegia. However, the cavernous sinus contains multiple cranial nerves (CNs), including CN III, IV, VI, V1, and V2. A lesion in this location would typically cause deficits in more than just CN III. This patient has preserved abduction, indicating intact CN VI function, which makes an isolated CN III palsy more likely than a cavernous sinus process.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetic mononeuropathy can cause oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy. However, this condition is ischemic in nature and affects the central microvasculature of the nerve while typically sparing the superficial parasympathetic fibers. This results in a 'pupil-sparing' CN III palsy, in which motor function is lost (ptosis, 'down and out' gaze) but pupillary size and reactivity remain normal. This patient's fixed, dilated pupil makes an ischemic cause, such as diabetic neuropathy, unlikely.
questions.hint: A complete oculomotor nerve palsy with a fixed, dilated pupil suggests an external compressive lesion rather than an ischemic one.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with sudden onset of drooping of his left eyelid and double vision. He has a 15-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, the left eye is positioned “down and out” and cannot move medially or vertically, but the pupil remains reactive to light. There are no other focal neurological deficits or headaches.
Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Posterior communicating artery aneurysm compressing the oculomotor nerve
Microvascular ischemic involvement of the oculomotor nerve
Inflammatory demyelination of the oculomotor nerve
Migrainous neuropathy affecting the oculomotor nerve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A posterior communicating artery aneurysm can compress the oculomotor nerve, affecting the superficial parasympathetic fibers and causing an enlarged, poorly reactive pupil. However, the reactive pupil in this patient suggests an ischemic rather than compressive etiology, as seen in diabetic neuropathy, where the central nerve fibers are affected while the peripheral fibers are spared.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, microvascular ischemia can lead to infarction of the oculomotor nerve. This primarily affects the central somatic fibers responsible for extraocular muscle control and eyelid elevation, resulting in the 'down and out' eye position and ptosis. The peripheral parasympathetic fibers, which control pupillary constriction, are typically spared due to their robust blood supply, resulting in a reactive pupil. This pattern is characteristic of diabetic third nerve neuropathy, marked by motor involvement with preserved pupillary function.

Key learning point: Diabetic third nerve neuropathy typically presents with a third nerve palsy that spares the pupil, due to ischemic damage affecting somatic fibers but sparing parasympathetic fibers.

C) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory demyelination, as seen in conditions like multiple sclerosis, typically affects younger patients and presents with additional neurological signs. This elderly patient with diabetes and a pupil-sparing oculomotor nerve palsy suggests microvascular ischemia rather than demyelination, which would likely involve other neurological deficits.

D) INCORRECT:

Migrainous neuropathy can cause transient ophthalmoplegia, typically in younger patients with migraine history. This 68-year-old patient with diabetes and a pupil-sparing oculomotor nerve palsy is more consistent with ischemic neuropathy. Migrainous neuropathy is rare in the elderly and usually involves migraine symptoms, which are absent here.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening double vision and drooping of the right eyelid for 2 days. He has also had frequent headaches over the past month. Physical examination shows right eye deviation laterally and inferiorly at rest. The right pupil is dilated and does not react to light or with accommodation. The patient's diplopia improves slightly on looking to the right. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s findings?

choices.text: Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery
Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus has a highly variable clinical manifestation because of the number of cranial nerves passing through the region (CN III, IV, V1, V2, VI). Patients with cavernous sinus thrombosis can present with headaches and unilateral CN III palsy. However, this patient does not have the typical signs of fever, unilateral periorbital edema, photophobia, and chemosis seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis. Moreover, isolated involvement of CN III without damage to any of the other cranial nerves that pass through the cavernous sinus would be uncommon.

B) INCORRECT:

Ischemia of the intraneural arterioles of CN III is commonly caused by nonenzymatic glycosylation of vasculature, in which prolonged periods of hyperglycemia (due to diabetes mellitus) lead to irreversible damage to small vessels. The inner part of CN III provides motor output to the extraocular muscles and is most sensitive to ischemia because of its reliance on diffusion for oxygen and nutrients. However, ischemic damage to CN III typically manifests with a pupil-sparing palsy.

C) CORRECT:

An aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery can cause compression of the nearby oculomotor nerve (CN III). Compressive lesions are characterized by pupillary involvement due to injury to the outer parasympathetic layer of CN III (which controls pupil dilation, light reactivity, and accommodation). Additional injury to the deeper somatic fibers of the nerve (which control extraocular muscles) is responsible for this patient's ptosis and “down and out” gaze.

Acute CN III palsy due to a cerebral aneurysm is very concerning for imminent rupture. A patient presenting with dilated pupils and a history of recent headaches should undergo an urgent MRI with MR angiography.
Image Description:

Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

D) INCORRECT:

Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) causes internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). When present bilaterally, INO is often a sign of multiple sclerosis. Lesions in the MLF cause horizontal diplopia and impaired adduction on lateral gaze in one eye, with nystagmus in the contralateral abducting eye. However, this patient does not have nystagmus and the diplopia in INO is only present when the patient's gaze moves towards the contralateral side of the lesion, in contrast to this patient's resting diplopia. Moreover, INO would not explain this patient's eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, or the dilated pupil.

E) INCORRECT:

Enlarging pituitary adenomas typically present with bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the optic chiasm. Sufficiently large adenomas can cause headaches and CN III palsy due to compression resulting from lateral extension of the tumor. However, a tumor at the optic chiasm is unlikely to cause an isolated CN III palsy.

F) INCORRECT:

Infarctions of the posterior cerebral artery cause damage to the third cranial nerve nucleus in the midbrain. Patients present with ipsilateral CN III palsy and diplopia, which are seen in this case. However, such an infarct would usually also damage other parts of the midbrain, causing further neurologic features based on the structures involved (e.g., contralateral hemiataxia, cerebellar tremor). Furthermore, because the innervation of the levator palpebrae superioris muscles is supplied by a single subnucleus in the midbrain, ptosis would be expected to be bilateral, not unilateral as seen here.
questions.hint: Double vision, eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, and a dilated pupil that does not react to light point to oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy, with both somatic and parasympathetic involvement.

An aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery can cause compression of the nearby oculomotor nerve (CN III). Compressive lesions are characterized by pupillary involvement due to injury to the outer parasympathetic layer of CN III (which controls pupil dilation, light reactivity, and accommodation). Additional injury to the deeper somatic fibers of the nerve (which control extraocular muscles) is responsible for this patient's ptosis and “down and out” gaze. Acute CN III palsy due to a cerebral aneurysm is very concerning for imminent rupture. A patient presenting with dilated pupils and a history of recent headaches should undergo an urgent MRI with MR angiography.
Image Description:

Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

B) INCORRECT:

Sufficiently large pituitary macroadenomas can cause headaches and cranial nerve palsies due to compression resulting from parasellar growth and extension of the tumor into the cavernous sinus. However, visual field defects on confrontational visual field testing (e.g., temporal hemianopsia) would be expected and an isolated CN III palsy is an unlikely presentation of a pituitary macroadenoma.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus has a highly variable clinical manifestation because of the number of cranial nerves passing through the region (CN III, IV, V1, V2, VI). Patients with cavernous sinus thrombosis can present with headaches and unilateral CN III palsy. However, this patient does not have the typical signs of fever, unilateral periorbital edema, photophobia, and chemosis seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis. Moreover, isolated involvement of CN III without damage to any of the other cranial nerves that pass through the cavernous sinus would be uncommon.

D) INCORRECT:

Ischemia of the intraneural arterioles of CN III is commonly caused by nonenzymatic glycosylation of vasculature, in which prolonged periods of hyperglycemia (due to diabetes mellitus) lead to irreversible damage to small vessels. The inner part of CN III provides motor output to the extraocular muscles and is most sensitive to ischemia because of its reliance on diffusion for oxygen and nutrients. However, ischemic damage to CN III typically manifests with a pupil-sparing palsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) causes internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). When present bilaterally, INO is often a sign of multiple sclerosis. Lesions in the MLF cause horizontal diplopia and impaired adduction on lateral gaze in one eye, with nystagmus in the contralateral abducting eye. However, this patient does not have nystagmus and the diplopia in INO is only present when the patient's gaze moves towards the contralateral side of the lesion, in contrast to this patient's resting diplopia. Moreover, INO would not explain this patient's eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, or the dilated pupil.

F) INCORRECT:

Infarctions of the posterior cerebral artery cause damage to the third cranial nerve nucleus in the midbrain. Patients can present with ipsilateral CN III palsy but such an infarct would usually also damage other parts of the midbrain, causing further neurologic features based on the structures involved (e.g., contralateral hemiataxia, cerebellar tremor). Furthermore, because the innervation of the levator palpebrae superioris muscles is supplied by a single subnucleus in the midbrain, ptosis would be expected to be bilateral, not unilateral as seen here.
questions.hint: Double vision, eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, and a dilated pupil that does not react to light point to oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy, with both somatic and parasympathetic involvement.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office because of worsening double vision and drooping of the right eyelid for 2 days. He has also had frequent headaches over the past month. Physical examination shows right eye deviation laterally and inferiorly at rest. The right pupil is dilated and does not react to light or with accommodation. The patient's diplopia improves slightly on looking to the right. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s findings?

choices.text: Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus has a highly variable clinical manifestation because of the number of cranial nerves passing through the region (CN III, IV, V1, V2, VI). Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), when present bilaterally, is often a sign of multiple sclerosis. Moreover, INO would not explain this patient's eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, or the dilated pupil.

D) INCORRECT:

Enlarging pituitary adenomas typically present with bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the optic chiasm. Sufficiently large adenomas can cause headaches and CN III palsy due to compression resulting from lateral extension of the tumor. However, a tumor at the optic chiasm is unlikely to cause an isolated CN III palsy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of weakness of the left side of her face, loss of taste, as well as dryness and redness of her left eye. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows an inability to puff the left cheek and close her left eye. An MRI of the brain shows a contrast-enhancing mass in the posterior fossa. The patient's symptoms are most likely caused by compression of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This structure, which emerges from the posterior surface of the brainstem, is the trochlear nerve (CN IV). CN IV lies in the posterior cranial fossa just below the free edge of the tentorium. Compression of CN IV, which innervates the superior oblique muscle, would present with diplopia and extorsion of the eye.
Image Description:

Trochlear nerve palsy (here of the left eye) causes paralysis of the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle. This leads to hypertropia (upwards deviation) that increases in adduction, excyclotorsion (outward rotation) of the affected eye and slight limitation of abduction. The findings may be discrete.

Patients typically present with vertical or oblique diplopia. Hypertropia and diplopia usually increases with ipsilateral head-tilt and decreases with contralateral head-tilt. Patients may adopt the latter as a compensatory posture (upper right of image).

B) INCORRECT:

B corresponds to the trigeminal nerve (CN V), which emerges from the anterolateral surface of the pons. A posterior fossa tumor can compress CN V, and potentially result in redness and dryness in the eye (due to neurotrophic keratopathy) as well as sensory loss in the tongue. However, somatosensations (e.g., touch, pain, temperatures) in the tongue rather than taste sensation are lost in patients with a compressed CN V and features of facial muscle weakness (e.g., lagophthalmos, inability to puff the cheek) would not be expected. Instead, affected patients have weakness in the muscles of mastication and sensory deficits in the face.

C) INCORRECT:

The structure indicated by C is the abducens nerve (CN VI), which emerges from the anteromedial region of the pontomedullary junction. Compression of CN VI, which innervates the lateral rectus muscle, would present with diplopia and esotropia.
Image Description:

Abducens nerve palsy (here of the left eye) impairs the function of the lateral rectus muscle. This causes esotropia (medial deviation) of the affected eye and limits its abduction. Patients present with horizontal diplopia that worsens when turning the gaze to the affected side or looking at distant objects.

D) CORRECT:

This structure is the facial nerve (CN VII), which emerges from the lateral part of the pontomedullary junction (cerebellopontine angle) medial to the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). CN VII provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and orbicularis oculi. CN VII also contains nerve fibers that relay taste sensation from the anterior ⅔ of the tongue (via the chorda tympani) and parasympathetic efferents to the lacrimal gland. Compression of CN VII can, therefore, cause an inability to puff the cheeks, decreased taste sensation, lagophthalmos, and a dry eye, as seen here. The most likely cause of CN VII compression at the cerebellopontine angle is a schwannoma. Schwannomas can develop in any cranial or peripheral nerve but most commonly arises from CN VIII (i.e., acoustic neuroma/vestibular schwannoma).
Image Description:

Ventral view

E) INCORRECT:

This structure, which emerges from the most lateral part of the pontomedullary junction (cerebellopontine angle), is the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). Compression of CN VIII would present with sensorineural hearing loss and vestibular symptoms (e.g., nystagmus, vertigo).

F) INCORRECT:

F corresponds to the accessory nerve (CN XI), a structure that has roots emerging from the lateral region of the inferior medulla and upper cervical cord. The accessory nerve passes through the posterior cranial fossa before exiting the skull via the jugular foramen. Compression of this nerve would manifest as an inability to elevate the shoulder (ipsilateral trapezius weakness) and/or an inability to turn the head away from the affected side (ipsilateral sternocleidomastoid weakness), which are not seen here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of facial nerve palsy.
